prompts: Hey there, manager! Having a 1-to-1? Here's a random question you can try asking:
Not sure what to talk about at your 1-to-1? How about this:
Awkward silence at your 1-to-1? See if this helps to get the discussion going:

categories.title: Organization Matters
prompts: Here's a question concerning the organization:
So you want to talk about organization matters, great! Here's a question to discuss:
questions: What’s one thing we’d be *crazy* not to do within the next 6 months to improve the organization?
If you were top dog in the organization, what would you change?
Are there any aspects of our culture you wish you could change?
What is the #1 Problem at our company? Why?
What would convince you to leave for a job somewhere else?
Is everyone pulling their weight on the team?
What’s an inexpensive thing we could do to improve our office environment for the team?
Who on the team do you have the most difficulty working with? Why?
Who is kicking ass on the team? What have they done?
Are you uncomfortable giving any of your peers constructive criticism? If so, why?
Have you seen something recently and thought to yourself ‘I wish we’d done that’?
Is there something we should measure in the company that we currently don’t?
Have you seen someone here do great work that’s gone unnoticed?
Are there things you don’t know about the company that you feel you should know?

categories.title: Personal Development
prompts: It's important to develop your staff. Try asking:
Good choice! Here's a question on personal development:
questions: What work are you doing here that you feel is most in line with your long term goals?
What are your super powers? What powers would you like to develop?
Do you feel challenged at work? Are you learning new things?
What skills would you like to develop right now?
Who in the company would you like to learn from? What do you want to learn?
What additional training or education would you like?
Are there any roles in the company you’d like to learn more about?
Do you feel like you’re making progress on your big goals here? Why or why not?
What’s one thing we could do today to help you with your long term goals?
Do you feel we’re helping you advance your career at a pace you would like?
Is there any part of the organization you wish you were able to interact with more?
Is there an area outside your current role where you feel you could be contributing?
Is there anyone at the company you wish you could apprentice under for a few weeks?

categories.title: Work Satisfaction
prompts: Here's a question about work satisfaction:
Try this question to see if your staff is satisfied at work:
questions: Is your job what you expected when you accepted it?
Are you happy with your recent work? Why or why not?
What’s something you feel is undervalued that you contribute to the team?
What part of your job do you wish you didn’t have to do?
What do you feel is your greatest accomplishment here?
Are you afraid of anything at work?
Are there any benefits we don’t offer that you’d like to see us offer?

categories.title: Establishing Rapport
prompts: Try this question to establish trust and rapport:
Awesome - building rapport with your staff is important. Try this question:
questions: How are you? How is life outside of work?
What do you like to do in your free time? What are your hobbies?
What drives you? What motivates you to come to work each day?
What’s one thing we could change about work for you that would improve your personal life?
What would you like to know about me?

categories.title: Coaching
prompts: Help your staff deal with problems/issues with a coaching question:
Here's a question to initiate some coaching with your staff:
questions: What’s a recent situation you wish you handled differently? What would you change?
What’s an area of your work you want to improve?
In what aspect of your job you would like more help or coaching?
What are your big dreams in life? Are you making progress on them?
What are your long term goals? Have you thought about them?

categories.title: Receiving Feedback
prompts: Great choice - feedback goes both ways. Try asking this:
Managers shouldn't just give feedback, but also seek feedback from staff. Here's a question to solicit feedback:
questions: What is something I could do better? What is a criticism you have for me?
What is one (or more?) criticism you have about me?
What aspects of your work would you like more or less direction from me?
What do you like about my management style? What do you dislike?
What have your past managers done that you’d like me to also do or not do?
What’s your favorite thing I do as a manager of this team I should keep doing?
What could I do to make you enjoy your work more?
